content.description: long reach   then a nice heel hook
content.location: across river    down stream   up hill    from the cheese grator

content.description: Start low right and traverse left on top ledge
content.location: Last  stand alone boulder down streamClose to the ridge line

content.description: nice 2 hand side jug   upper left ledge
content.protection: 3-4 pads   maybe will need sticks to support pads from getting wet
content.location: Right of the parking lot    all the way down the path down to the falls   next to the slip n slide water fall

content.description: This is the furthest upstream route on the Bill Wall.  Although it looks pretty easy from the ground, don't let the features fool you.  There are a lot of seemingly good hand holds that are tough to get a grip on.  Be careful of lose rocks.  Soft/wet sandstone holds can be precarious.
content.location: You can access the anchors at the top of the climb by taking the trail to the right of the overlook.  Walk past the no swimming sign and take the first trail that leads left to the cliffs edge.  You will come to a point where the trail drops down about three feet.   You can access the bottom of the climb either by following the main trail down to the river and back-tracking along the wall, or by climbing back past the overlook and taking the first trail to the left of it.

content.description: Sit-start on crimply ledge Bump up the arete to a solid hold where you can knee-bar the area between the rocks Use only the left rock for hands, right for feet all the way to the top.
content.location: Parking in the Berea Falls parking lot, find a way down to the river. The rock will be just below some of the cliffs about 100 feet downriver of the wooden overlook.

content.description: Sit startLeft hand on sloper right hand on crimpBump right hand to Arete with a heel hook right in front of right handget both hands to the top point and top out
content.location: Down hill from Crackhead ClamRight side of the Cheese Grater
way left from the parking lot, at the farthest most ridge line.

content.description: side pull match to left hand crimpright heel hook
content.location: down hill from crack head clamin the cluster of the 3 large boulders near the river

content.description:
Knee Bar, Sloppers, Crimp, Side Pull, Heel Hook, Finger Pocket, Long Stretch    This problem has it all 

  start as low as possible   then Knee Bar the chimney   Nice 2 finger hold far right   Heel hook the iron nipple 

  DO NOT TOUCH THE OBVIOUS LARGE LEDGE!!!!
content.location: mid ridge line    as soon as you enter the left trail

content.description: crimp left hand start   top out is rough...   heel hook up or mantle.
content.location: Across the river   last set of boulder walls all the way down river

content.description: start on smaller boulder and dyno left to ledge that has 1 jug and rest sloper
content.protection: 3 pads    1-2 spotters you may fall into the river 50ft down a cliff
content.location: upstream along ridge linedirectly below the lookout over hang

content.description: That right toe clingAnd that right hand, right angled edge with pulling pressure feels so good
content.location: Just down hill from crackhead clamIn the cluster of 3 large boulder by the river

content.description: 3 moves but i like it!   top out is funky
content.protection: 1 pad    1 spotter is only necessary because of the log at the base
content.location: closer to the ridge line    directly above the cheese grator about 300ft

content.description: FLAT slab of iron deposit thats at an 85 degree angle, couple of nipple pinch crimps, with lots of jugs at the top.   DONT FALL YOUR KNEES WILL BE SHREDDED LIKE CHEESE
content.location: along the river   valley parkway road side

content.description:
This is a classic Berea Sandstone climb.  It is especially difficult when wet.  The crux of this problem is getting to the second large handhold up the crack.  You'll have to stretch for it.  It's harder than it looks.  

 There is also no super convenient place for your belayer to stand.  Standing further down the drainage ditch would probably be the safest.
content.protection: There is a tree at the top of this climb that can be used for an anchor for this route.
content.location: This is the furthest downstream route on the Bill Wall.  You can access the base of the climb by walking left of the wooden lookout, then crossing under it.  You can anchor to the slanted tree at the top of the route. The walk down to the base is a bit slippery when wet so be careful when walking down after setting the anchor.

content.description: Under long hand start a long with a single left footLeft hand to crimpRight hand topSolid right foot top out
content.location: Just down hill from the crackhead clam in the large boulder cluster near the river

content.description: Berea sandstone, identical to Chippewa creek but with more iron deposits.BRING YOUR BRUSHESa few projects in the works the grades are steadily progressing newly discovered - though this was well climbed in the mid 90s by a select few that knew of its existence.always people hiking... pot smokers especially.
